name: Soma
botanicalName: Unknown - possibly Ephedra, Sarcostemma, Amanita, or extinct species
description: The legendary plant and sacred drink of Vedic ritual, praised in over 100 hymns of Rigveda. Soma grants immortality (amrita), divine vision, communion with gods, and supernatural strength. True identity lost to history - one of archaeology's great mysteries.

vedicDescription.plant: Stalks or stems (not leaves or fruits), leafless, juicy when fresh
vedicDescription.preparation: Crushed/pressed between stones, filtered through wool, mixed with milk/water
vedicDescription.effects: Divine ecstasy, fearlessness, strength, immortality, union with gods

mythologicalSignificance.deification: Soma personified as god (Soma/Chandra - moon god)
mythologicalSignificance.indrasDrink: Indra's favorite - gives strength to battle demons
mythologicalSignificance.amrita: Elixir of immortality sought by gods and demons
mythologicalSignificance.cosmicOrigin: Brought from heaven by eagle, stolen from demons

uses: Vedic sacrifice - pressed, filtered, offered to Agni and Indra
Priestly consumption - brahmins drank soma after offering to gods
Divine communion - soma enabled humans to communicate with devas
Strength ritual - warriors drank before battle
Immortality quest - seeking amrita through soma sacrifice
Moon worship - soma identified with lunar deity Chandra
rituals: Soma Yajna - elaborate Vedic ritual pressing and offering soma
Agnicayana - soma essential to complex fire altar ceremony
Pravargya - heating milk ceremony preparatory to soma
Ashwamedha - horse sacrifice included soma offering
Three pressings - morning, noon, evening extractions

candidatePlants.ephedra: Ephedra (ma huang) - stimulant, grows in mountains, used in Zoroastrian haoma
candidatePlants.sarcostemma: Sarcostemma acidum - milky juice, leafless stems, still used by some

sacredSignificance: Over 100 Rigvedic hymns praise Soma. Entire Mandala IX dedicated to Soma. Bridge between human and divine. Key to Vedic religion. Loss of soma knowledge = loss of authentic Vedic practice. Soma = inspiration for all existence.
culturalContext: True soma lost by classical Hindu period. Substitutes used in rituals. Debate ongoing 2000+ years. Soma mythology influenced Zoroastrian haoma, Buddhist amrita. Symbol of spiritual quest and lost wisdom.
modernSubstitutes: Putika (various herbs) - listed alternatives in texts
safetyWarnings: Original plant unknown - no preparation possible
This entry is for HISTORICAL and MYTHOLOGICAL study ONLY
